title: 114_s3051
content: The Act may be cited as the "Puppies Assisting Wounded Servicemembers (PAWS) Act of 2016". The findings of Congress highlight the prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder among returning Armed Forces members from Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom. Dogs can help mitigate the stress response associated with PTSD, improving symptoms such as anxiety, fear, social isolation, and sleep disturbances. The Department of Veterans Affairs is conducting a pilot program to provide service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is conducting a pilot program to provide service dogs to eligible veterans diagnosed with severe post-traumatic stress disorder. The program includes furnishing veterinary health insurance for each service dog provided. The pilot program provides service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder who have not improved with established therapies. Veterans must have completed treatment, show significant symptoms, served after September 11, 2001, and continue to see a physician to remain eligible for veterinary health insurance. The pilot program provides service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder who have not improved with established therapies. Veterans must see a physician at a medical facility not less frequently than once every 90 days. The Secretary shall enter into contracts for the procurement and training of service dogs with certified providers, including one-on-one training for each service dog for a minimum of 30 hours over a period of not less than 90 days. The pilot program provides service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder. The service dogs are trained by certified providers and recipients stay at an in-house facility for at least ten days, receiving 30 hours of training. All service dogs must pass the American Kennel Club Canine Good Citizen test. The Secretary is limited to spending $27,000 on each service dog. Follow-up support services are provided for the life of the service dog. The pilot program provides service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder, in addition to other treatment modalities. A GAO study will evaluate the program's effectiveness in helping veterans live normally and improving relevant metrics like PCL scores. The pilot program provides service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder to improve psychosocial function, reduce symptoms, and decrease reliance on prescription medication. The Comptroller General will make recommendations on the program's continuation or expansion. $10,000,000 is authorized for the program annually from 2017 to 2022. The pilot program providing service dogs to veterans with severe post-traumatic stress disorder will have its funding reduced by $10,000,000 annually for the Office of Human Resources and Administration of the Department of Veterans Affairs from 2017 to 2022. The program will terminate five years after the enactment of the Act.
